ratings.comment:
Nice person, but lectures are a bit old fashioned(talk a lot about historical stuff and physical layer) and not recorded. Must read textbook in great detail and take notes carefully.
This isn't a surprise if you look at his research focus, so decide yourself if you want a more modern style & content (take with Ming Liu) or Barford.

Fairly big class, but Prof. Barford makes it feel like a discussion and the focus is on understanding the material. Really interesting, and Barford is so willing to go into in depth explanations during lecture. Extremely nontechnical course, tests are easy if you just listen/engage in lecture (do not skip class), plus 3 month-long Python projects.
Gas professor. Definitely the best CS professor I've had.

Amazing professor! Teaching a class as difficult as this and making it easy to understand is his specialty. There are a lot of big projects you work on and they are pretty difficult but he delivers lectures like Steve Jobs and his very passionate about his job. Would 100% recommend.

He's a great lecturer but in every other aspect the class was kinda meh. The projects are fine. The quizzes are not super hard. This class is great for undergrad students who want to learn stuff from scratch but probably not as helpful for grad students who know a lot of this stuff and are really trying to get into the details.
Never choose his course. It is not a CS course, it is a history and literature course, never show codes or PPT, just the blackboard.

Absolutely amazing professor, it hurts me to see such poor reviews on here. His lectures are so captivating and interesting, imbuing his passion for the topic in his students. He truly does know how to teach a class, and actually cares for his students. He takes things very casually and the overall vibe of the class is super chill.

Fantastic lecturer; the best professor that I've had and probably will have during the course of my undergraduate degree in college. Lecture is behind schedule because he loves answering questions and does not like to read off slides. A pleasure to have him as a professor. I average around 50% attendance maximum in cs, i will be at all his lectures

As other people said, projects and quizzes are not related to the lecture. Quizzes questions are very detailed. Besides, we are really behind the schedule. I regret taking this course with Prof.Barford.
cool af

Lectures are fine but too bad they are not very related to exams and not at all to projects. The professor asks super detailed questions on the quizzes. Don't take this class with Barford unless you want to memorize every single piece of the notes.

You can tell Barford not cares at all about his students, especially when the class is now moved online amid this pandemic. He just offers a bunch of pre-recorded lecture videos he had last year at Epic and leave all learnings for the rest of the semester to the students so they have to sit at home and watch a 3-hour-long recording every week.

Professor Barford is a decent lecturer. There wasn't a time where I was confused about anything. He's average when it comes to explaining algorithms. However, his quizzes are rather unfair as some questions have very subjective answers, and every 2 pts lost makes you lose 1% of your grade. "You have to choose the best answer". Ugh.

Prof. Barford's lectures are very interesting and inspirational and have a very good flow in them, but he is not very good at explaining details of protocols and network algorithms. Explanations are normally inefficient and redundant. Projects are helpful in understanding materials (somewhat). So read the book before lectures if you take his class

Not a college level computer science course. Lectures are low-quality and incoherent. Projects require using a contrived python framework called switchyard which has little real-world relevance. Avoid cs640 with Paul Baford if possible, instead try to take it with Aditya Akella if available, or just read W. Richard Stevens' TCP/IP illustrated
Good lectures, but too bad theyre irrelevant to projects/quizzes. If you think this is a CS class, think again. Its everything but CS (mainly history, physics, with a hint of EE)

TLDR: Never, ever take a class with Barford. He often snaps at people who ask questions or makes fun of them, if he even takes questions at all. He is lazy and does not update course materials, so you are left guessing on exams. Always cancels office hours. Projects unrelated to lecture material. Really disappointed. Needs to be audited.
Engaging and solid lecturer. Does a great job explaining introductory topics in Networking. Exams and Quizzes were multiple choice for the first time and require a decent amount of studying.

Professor Barford is highly knowledgeable in advance networks topics. His classes are very interactive, creating a healthy discussion environment for students to express ideas and ask relevant questions. His lectures in general are very inspiring.

Professor Barford is very knowledgeable and this comes across during class. With that being said, he can also be intimidating and rather flippant about comments/questions asked during lecture. Tests are very lecture-heavy, so make sure to take good and specific notes--and this shouldn't be too hard because he does explain content clearly.
Professor Barford does not respond to questions in lecture. He is sarcastic and unhelpful.
Very good lecturer. A lot of details are presented in this course, and he makes them all crystal clear, though it is difficult to keep track of them all. Quizzes/exams are difficult.
Super difficult quizzes and exams which focus on memorizing small details on subjects. Lectures were interesting for the most part, but a lot of information is presented in the lectures.

Barford is very knowledgable in the material.  He takes difficult topics and makes them easy to understand.  He teaches them so clearly that I rarely relied on the book to reinforce the concepts.  He lectures on everything you need to know in the quizzes and exams, and he makes clear what to expect on them.

Barford is an unbelievably good resource for students. His copious amount of knowledge in the field as well as generally phenomenal insight into any situation made this class phenomenal. Genuinely cares about your product and your learning.
He is a good teacher. But the exam is too weird that you can only know what he is asking after you see the answers. If you would take his class, then good luck.

Excellent teacher and very knowledgeable in the field.  A high-level mover and shaker, so it's exciting to having him teaching an undergraduate class.  On the down-side, the guy cannot write exams and his exams can be extremely hard and pedantic with an emphasis on memorization of minute details.  Study hard, do all the work and you may do well.
